factoid: Sónya clung to Nicholas's arm.
Sónya looked eagerly toward Nicholas's eyes.
Sónya was sixteen.
Sónya was very pretty.
Sónya gazed at Nicholas.
Sónya smiled.
Sónya held her breath.
Nicholas gave Sónya a grateful look.
Nicholas was expectant.
Nicholas was looking for someone.
The old countess had not yet come.
Steps were heard at the door.
The steps were so rapid that they could hardly be Nicholas's mother's.
Nicholas's mother was dressed in a new gown.
Nicholas's mother had not known the gown had been made since Nicholas had left.
All the others let Nicholas go.
Nicholas ran to his mother.
Nicholas's mother fell on Nicholas's breast.
Nicholas's mother sobbed.
Nicholas's mother pressed her face to the cold braiding of Nicholas's hussar's jacket.
Denísov entered the room unnoticed by anyone.
Denísov wiped his eyes at the sight.
Denísov introduced himself to the count.
Denísov said, 'Vasíli Denísov, your son's friend'.
The count kissed Denísov.
The count embraced Denísov.
The count said, 'Nicholas wrote us... Natásha, Véra, look! Here is Denísov!'.
Natásha looked at Denísov.
Véra looked at Denísov.
Natásha screamed, 'Darling Denísov!'
Natásha sprang to Denísov.
Natásha put her arms around Denísov.
Natásha kissed Denísov.
Denísov blushed.
Denísov smiled.
Denísov took Natásha's hand.
Denísov kissed Natásha's hand.
Denísov was shown to the room prepared for him.
The Rostóvs gathered round Nicholas in the sitting room.
The old countess sat beside Nicholas.
The old countess did not let go of Nicholas's hand.
The old countess kissed Nicholas's hand every moment.
The rest crowded round Nicholas.
The rest watched every movement, word, or look of Nicholas.
The rest never took their blissfully adoring eyes off Nicholas.
Nicholas's brother struggled for a place nearest to Nicholas.
Nicholas's sisters struggled for a place nearest to Nicholas.
Nicholas's brother and sisters disputed who should bring him tea.
Nicholas's brother and sisters disputed who should bring him a handkerchief.
Nicholas's brother and sisters disputed who should bring him a pipe.
Rostóv was very happy in the love they showed him.
The first moment of meeting was beatific.
Nicholas's present joy seemed insufficient after the first meeting.
Nicholas kept expecting something more.
The next morning, after the fatigue of their journey, the travelers slept until ten o'clock.
In the room next to their bedroom there was a confusion of sabers.
In the room next to their bedroom there were satchels.
In the room next to their bedroom there were sabretaches.
In the room next to their bedroom there were open portmanteaus.
In the room next to their bedroom there were dirty boots.
Two freshly cleaned pairs with spurs had just been placed by the wall.
The servants were bringing in jugs.
The servants were bringing in basins.
The servants were bringing in hot water for shaving.
The servants were bringing in well-brushed clothes.
There was a masculine odor.
There was a smell of tobacco.
Vasíli Denísov said, 'Hallo, Gwíska—my pipe!'
Wostóv told Vasíli Denísov to get up.
Rostóv rubbed his eyes.
Rostóv raised his disheveled head from the hot pillow.
Rostóv asked, 'Why, is it late?'.
Natásha answered, 'Late! It’s nearly ten o’clock'.
A rustle of starched petticoats came from the adjoining room.
The whispering and laughter of girls' voices came from the adjoining room.
The door was opened a crack.
A glimpse of something blue was seen.
Ribbons were seen.
Black hair was seen.
Merry faces were seen.
It was Natásha, Sónya, and Pétya who had come to see whether they were getting up.
Nicholas shouted, 'Get up!'
Natásha shouted again at the door.
Pétya had found sabers in the outer room.
Pétya seized the sabers.
Pétya opened the bedroom door.
Pétya shouted, 'Is this your saber?'.
The girls sprang aside.
Denísov hid his hairy legs under the blanket.
Denísov looked with a scared face at his comrade for help.
The door let Pétya in.
The door closed again.
A sound of laughter came from behind the door.
Natásha shouted, 'Nicholas! Come out in your dressing gown!'.
Pétya asked, 'Is this your saber?'.
Pétya addressed Denísov with servile deference.
